description: Today, I am indeed delighted and privileged to host the 57th Jamhuri Day celebrations here at Uhuru Gardens, the People’s Garden.
articleBody:
Read President Uhuru Kenyatta’s speech to the nation on Jamhuri Day, Sunday December 12, 2021

LEADERS FROM ACROSS THE ENTIRE SPECTRUM OF OUR NATION, MEMBERS OF THE DIPLOMATIC CORPS, LADIES AND GENTLEMEN, FELLOW KENYANS, HAPPY JAMHURI DAY!

Today, I am indeed delighted and privileged to host the 57th Jamhuri Day celebrations here at Uhuru Gardens, the People’s Garden.

This is the exact place where the Union Jack of the British colonizer was lowered and our National Flag hoisted on the midnight of 12th December, 1963.

And as we hoisted our National Flag here at the People’s Garden in Nairobi, a hero by the name of Kisoi Munyao raised the same flag at midnight of Independence Day at the peak of Mount Kenya. This being the highest point in our land, we wanted to declare to one and all that Kenya was finally independent.

The joy of December 12th is that we celebrate two critical milestones of our independence journey. And I say so because the transfer of power from the British colonizers to our Founding Fathers took place in three steps over a period of 18 months.

The first step was achieved after the May 27th election of 1963. This election ushered in our self-rule on June 1st, 1963.

And with this step, the First Prime Minister of Kenya, Mzee Jomo Kenyatta became the Head of Government. But the Queen of England remained the Head of State. This means that we were free; but not free.

Six months later, the second milestone was achieved when we gained independence on December 12th, 1963. On this day, we gathered here at the Garden of the People, hoisted our national flag and played our national anthem for the first time.

And as we did this, we were reminded that our National Flag is not just a piece of cloth decorated with ink; or a sentimental display of colours without history.

Our Flag is a symbol of the national wounds and the scars we bear from the liberation war. It is a picture of the battles we fought; those we won and those we lost. And because the ultimate act of every great warrior is to lay down his weapon, the shield and spears on our National Flag symbolize victory.

But even with independence, a national flag and a national anthem, the Queen of England continued to serve as Kenya’s Head of State. This meant that we were free; but not free.

It took us one full year to get to the third and final milestone of our liberation. This happened on December 12th, 1964 when the Queen of England vacated her position as Head of State. And with this act, Kenya transitioned into a full Republic or Jamhuri marking the total liberation of our country.

On this memorable day in 1964, we returned to this Garden of the People to launch the Republic of Kenya and inaugurate its First President. And on the same day, the Governor-General, who became the last expatriate occupant of Government House, left Kenya.

To commemorate this change of guard, the First President planted a Mugumo tree at the exact spot where our flag had been hoisted at midnight of December 12th, 1963. That 57-year-old tree stands tall and proud to my right as a symbol of our struggle dating back 100 years ago in the 1920s.

This December 12th is therefore a joyous day for Kenya because we mark the 58th Anniversary of our Independence and the 57th Celebration of our becoming a Republic.

As we mark this historic day, some will tell you that history is meaningless, unnecessary, useless and irrelevant to the concerns of the present. I beg to differ. History provides invaluable lessons to be learnt and gives context to the present. By looking back, we are better able to look forward.

Learning from the past means we can build on its good, avoid its mistakes and most importantly it is a constant reminder of the ugly. So that even, as we forgive, we should never forget.

Fellow Kenyans, Ladies and Gentlemen, Why did our Founding Fathers choose Uhuru Gardens as the place to celebrate Independence Day in 1963 and the republic status in 1964? Why did they want generations to memorize about our history, the untold atrocities visited upon our people and the evil associated with colonial rule?

The grounds on which we sit here today were also known as the Langata Concentration Camp. During the liberation war, this concentration camp was the most notorious clearing house for our liberation fighters.

In fact, it is estimated that up to 10,000 of our gallant and most feared liberators were confined in this camp at some point or another. And most of them did not survive the wrath of the colonizer.

Langata Camp has been described in the books of history as resembling the Nazi Camps in Germany, both in its psychological warfare and its methods of brutality. In fact, using ‘quack scientists’, the colonizers argued that devotion to the cause of Mau Mau was a mental illness. And the only way to deal with it was by creating mass detention camps where ‘shock therapy’ and torture would be administered as a cure.

And that was part of the logic they used to create the Langata Concentration Camp where we are seated today.

By creating this garden as a place of remembrance, our Founding Fathers wanted generations to recall the darkness of our colonial past, but not to be stuck in the pessimism that dark memories can breed. They wanted us to turn darkness into positive energy the way they did it in the concentration camps.

Instead of breaking down in the camps, colonial brutality only made them stronger. But there are other reasons why our Founding Fathers brought us to this place of national remembrance.

Each time we gather here, they wanted us to face our national fears and demons with courage. More so because, no condition is permanent. They wanted us to “…never question in the dark, decisions we made in the light”. Mainly because the long walk to freedom was a walk of faith.

Most of our liberators had no idea whether or when freedom would come. In fact, they confessed in their memoires that many times they had doubt that their cause would ever see the light of the day.

And although their walk to freedom was long and hard, the only thing that sustained them was the burning conviction of the rightness of their cause. They were troubled on every side, but not distressed. They were perplexed, but did not despair.

Fellow Kenyans, Ladies and Gentlemen, Whenever we congregate at this place of remembrance, we are called to renew the Soul of the Nation. We are called to appreciate the pain felt and sacrifices made, by those who went before us.

The fallen soldiers and heroes buried in unmarked graves in prisons and camps all over the country. That is why the project under construction before you at this site was initiated.

Apart from being a place of remembrance and healing, this place will be an arena where the past, the present and the future will converge.

When Kenyans walk through the Heroes Boulevard, their spirits will be edified by the sacrifices our liberators made. And at the end of this boulevard, there will be the tomb of the unknown warrior.

A warrior whose name we do not know, although he died in battle for our country. A warrior whose
mother let him go, and both mother and son sacrificed so that we can be free.

Once completed, this place of history will rekindle memories of our armed struggle, but also the good, the bad and the ugly of our history. At the Hall of Legends, it will bring alive our legendary ancestors including Mzee Jomo Kenyatta, Mekatilili wa Menza, Koitalel arap Samoei, Jaramogi Oginga Odinga and Nabongo Mumia among others.

At the Tunnel of Martys, we will have a solemn memorial to each and every Kenyan who lost their lives in the many watershed moments. These will range from the First to Second World War all the way to the victims of the post election violence of 2008.

In the Rope Gallery of this museum, a named rope will be dedicated to every one of the one thousand and ninety (1,090) heroic souls that were hanged during the colonial era. And at the Moments of Darkness Gallery, we shall display the histories of our lowest moments, the moments that we regret but are part of our history.

But not all galleries display sad news. The Hall of Innovation in this museum will celebrate the brilliant and game-changing ideas produced by Kenyans. This Hall will speak to the coming future and how our past has guided it. The Hall that is just behind me, marked by a spear pointing up, characterizes our latest exploits, our moments of great hope and national pride, and our bold path into the future.

This place will be a book of history and illumination of the future, weaved in hope, written in pictures, sculptures and historical artifacts. And although the place of remembrance is a place of national pain, it will also be an altar for historical forgiveness.

As Kenyans walk through the galleries of heroes and legends, they must forgive those who trespassed against us. However, they must also heed the call from our Founding Father when he said: “We will Forgive them; but we will NEVER Forget”. We must forgive our transgressors; but we must never forget their name.

Fellow Kenyans, Ladies and Gentlemen,
Finally, our Founding Fathers brought us to this Garden of remembrance to teach us that nation building is not a sprint; it is a relay. No single person or group of persons can make this undertaking alone.

Liberation was achieved because it was a product of teamwork. And it must be recorded that the Founding Fathers were not a team because they worked together. They were a team because they reinforced each other and had deep respect, and trust for one another.

They taught us that nation-building is like building a house. This endeavor is indeed a product of teamwork, not individualism. They built a firm foundation for a prosperous
Kenya.

Others amongst them built the walls and others roofed the house. Everyone had a role to play. And no role was greater than the other.

The same is today as it was then. We are building a house called Kenya and there is no place for one-manism in this project. It is the collective work of every able-bodied Kenyan.

And yes, we will disagree sometimes, but in our disagreements, we must remain respectful. In fact, respectful disagreements are what lead to reconciliation. More so because when we disagree, it is a sign that we are making progress.

The making of a nation and the building of a house are also living processes. They cannot be static; they must be dynamic.

Errors are made sometimes and renovations must correct them after the house is completed. In December 1991, we discovered that the one party system was a design error in our nationhood. And the advancement of the Republic had outlived its usefulness. We made renovations and changed the system.

In 2007, we ran into another architectural defect in our nation-building project. We discovered that the politics of exclusion in which the ‘winner takes it all’ was not good for our country. We were bold enough to change the Constitution and expand the executive in order to accommodate the excluded.

And when the former Prime Minister, Rt. Hon. Raila Odinga and I shook hands on March 8th, 2018, it was because we saw a crack on the wall of our nation. We had run two elections that costed the country KSh. 1 trillion in business loses and we were staring at a nation divided right in the middle.

Because we had disagreed respectfully, we knew that this was a mark of progress. It was difficult, but the necessity, the reason and the recognition that we as Kenyans needed each other, nation before self, as our forefathers had taught us to come together, reinforced our resolve. Therefore, the need to come together and mend the crack on the wall of our nation necessitated the first amendment to our Constitution.

And although it encountered some legal obstacles, I can only say that BBI is just a dream deferred. One day, someday, it will happen, because the country cannot survive ethnic majoritarianism and exclusion just as it cannot survive unfair and skewed representation. This is a design defect that we must fix.

Fellow Kenyans, Ladies and Gentlemen, This Garden of the People, therefore, is not just a place of remembrance. It was gifted to us as a place where generations shall tell stories of where we have come from, where we are and where we are going.

It is an arena of truth narrated before God; verified by history and reinforced by the acts of our Founding Fathers. And if it is a convergence point between our past and our present, it must also guide our future.

Allow me now to conclude with a thought about the future. If the Asian Tigers were at the same level of development as Kenya in 1963 and Kenya actually lent South Korea some money to implement its development plan in 1963, the question is what happened? Why were we unable to develop as fast as they did?

This future did not happen because we failed to plan for it. This future evaded us because we failed to imagine it. And I say so because imagination is more powerful than knowledge. For the past to have an impact on our future, we must constantly imagine and re-imagine the future.

As we envision the future, we are reminded that in eight years, our Economic Blue Print, that is, the Kenya Vision 2030 will have run its course. By then, Kenya will be home to a projected 63 million citizens; and as Kenya turns 100 in 2063, we will be home to 100 million citizens. For us to secure the elusive shared prosperity and inter-generational equity; we must be bold in our imagination of Kenya at 100.

But, our imagination cannot follow the popular path; it must follow the bold path. Indeed, Vision 2063 must be a bold imagination of what Kenya will be at 100 years. The solemn duty of framing of how this vision looks like is the task of our generation.

As our children walk through the Boulevard of Heroes in this park and play in the Pavilion of Reflection, what account of ourselves will we have left in this unedited place of history? It must be written in this unedited book of history that, we chose the bold path over the popular path. The Lion is “…not the strongest animal in the Savannah. Neither is it the biggest. Neither is it the most shrewd. But, it is the boldest”. And this attitude of boldness is what makes the lion, the King of the Jungle.

Indeed, this is the reason it is said that “…an army of sheep led by a lion can defeat an army of lions led by a sheep.” The future of Kenya, inspired by the past and the present, must be about brave imagination.

This is why I congratulate the 19th Infantry Battalion of the Kenya Army, whom I have coloured today. We must celebrate our Defence Forces because when they go to war in defense of our borders, they know too well that they will either return hoisting our national flag; or return wrapped in our national flag. This takes boldness and dedication.

Fellow Kenyans, Ladies and Gentlemen, Now I will end my address by keeping a promise I made. On the 20th October, 2021, I directed the Ministry of Energy to fast-track the implementation of the recommendations of the Presidential Taskforce on Power Purchase Agreements. I am pleased to note that the pathway to reduce the cost of electricity by over 30% is on course.

In honour of this pledge to the nation, and in response to the concerns over the high cost of electricity raised by both individual consumers and enterprises, I am pleased to announce to the nation that the reduction of the cost of electricity will be implemented in two tranches of 15% each; with the first 15% achieved through initial actions focusing on system and commercial losses, to be reflected in the December bills, and a further 15% reduction, in the first quarter of 2022.

In realizing the second tranche of the reduction in power bills, I note that the Ministry of Energy has initiated engagements with Independent Power Producers aimed at renegotiation of power purchase agreements; so as to give better value for money for consumers. I urge the power producers to demonstrate goodwill as we seek to make our energy sector a greater catalyst of our national development.

As we move to the New Year, 2022, I leave you with the words of our Founding President as he wished our new Republic a Merry Christmas 57 years ago. He urged our good men and women to be of service to their fellow countrymen. His New Year message was this: “…let everyone who is educated, teach others to read and write. Let every man who is healthy help a man who is sick. Let every man who has work find some prospect for a man that is poor and not employed. Let service be our inspiration for the future…”.

And with this message my beloved Countrymen, I wish you a Merry Christmas and a Prosperous New Year to you all.

But, our imagination cannot follow the popular path; it must follow the bold path. Indeed, Vision 2063 must be a bold imagination of what Kenya will be at 100 years. The solemn duty of framing of how this vision looks like is the task of our generation.

As our children walk through the Boulevard of Heroes in this park and play in the Pavilion of Reflection, what account of ourselves will we have left in this unedited place of history? It  must be written in this unedited book of history that, we chose the bold path over the popular path. The Lion is “…not the strongest animal in the Savannah. Neither is it the biggest. Neither is it the most shrewd. But, it is the boldest”. And this attitude of boldness is what makes the lion, the King of the Jungle.

Indeed, this is the reason it is said that “…an army of sheep led by a lion can defeat an army of lions led by a sheep.” The future of Kenya, inspired by the past and the present, must be about brave imagination.

This is why I congratulate the 19th Infantry Battalion of the Kenya Army, whom I have coloured today. We must celebrate our Defence Forces because when they go to war in defense of our borders, they know too well that they will either return hoisting our national flag; or return wrapped in our national flag. This takes boldness and dedication.

Fellow Kenyans, Ladies and Gentlemen, Now I will end my address by keeping a promise I made. On the 20th October, 2021, I directed the Ministry of Energy to fast-track the implementation of the recommendations of the Presidential Taskforce on Power Purchase Agreements. I am pleased to note that the pathway to reduce the cost of electricity by over 30% is on course.

In honour of this pledge to the nation, and in response to the concerns over the high cost of electricity raised by both individual consumers and enterprises, I am pleased to announce to the nation that the reduction of the cost of electricity will be implemented in two tranches of 15% each; with the first 15% achieved through initial actions focusing on system and commercial losses, to be reflected in the December bills, and a further 15% reduction, in the first quarter of 2022.

In realizing the second tranche of the reduction in power bills, I note that the Ministry of Energy has initiated engagements with Independent Power Producers aimed at renegotiation of  power purchase agreements; so as to give better value for money for consumers. I urge the power producers to demonstrate goodwill as we seek to make our energy sector a greater catalyst of our national development.

As we move to the New Year, 2022, I leave you with the words of our Founding President as he wished our new Republic a Merry Christmas 57 years ago. He urged our good men and women to be of service to their fellow countrymen. His New Year message was this: “…let everyone who is educated, teach others to read and write. Let every man who is healthy help a man who is sick. Let every man who has work find some prospect for a man that is poor and not employed. Let service be our inspiration for the future…”.

And with this message my beloved Countrymen, I wish you a Merry Christmas and a Prosperous New Year to you all.

headline: Form Three Student Dies While Playing Football
author: By Ivy Wanjiru

breadcrumbs.name: Form Three Student Dies While Playing Football

description: The student was playing the game within the school compound earlier in the day.
articleBody:
A Form Three student from Obera Boys Secondary School in Ndhiwa, Homa Bay County died on Sunday, December 5 while he was playing a football game with his schoolmates.

The student was playing the game within the school compound earlier in the day. His colleague disclosed that he hit the ball with his head and collapsed on the ground due to the alleged impact of the ball.

The students had rushed to save his life by picking him up and rushing him to the school administration building.

Central Kabuoch Location Chief Capis Olala told the media that students from the school had asked their teachers to quickly organize his transfer to the hospital but a vehicle was not immediately located, thus leading to a slight delay.

“I am aware that the school has contracted a local resident who owns a car to be offering transport services during emergencies. Unfortunately, he was not near when he was called,” the administrator said.

Teachers of the boys’ school had to look for alternative means of taking the injured student to the hospital.

Olala added that the school principal who was not present at the compound at the time of the incident had rushed back and facilitated the transport of the student to the hospital.

However, the student was unfortunately pronounced dead at Samari Medical centre in Rodi Kopany.

“The initial plan was that the student is taken to Homa Bay County Teaching and Referral hospital. The school administration later decided to divert to a private health centre for checkups before they proceed to the public health facility but the student was confirmed dead even before the doctors started attending to him,” Olala revealed.

The unfortunate demise sparked tension amongst the students who went beserk, destroying several school properties upon learning of the death of their colleague who was a students’ official.

They broke window panes with stones as well as hurled stones at the security lights, plunging the institution into darkness.

The protests were contained by security officers from Magina Police Post who were called upon to halt the tension.

Ndhiwa Sub-County Education Director Daniel Anekeya stated that his office was aware of the case.

The incident comes after Form Four students of Maranda High School in Siaya County were sent home indefinitely after they allegedly threatened to burn the institution on Tuesday evening, November 30, a case of students taking matters into their own hands.

The over 400 candidates were released by the school administration to go back home until further notice, according to one of the teachers who spoke to a local radio station on condition of anonymity.

The students had refused to sit for the internal mock exams and even threatened to burn the school.

The students were sent home following a decision by the school’s Board of Management that met at the institution on Thursday morning, December 2 following the threats that the students had allegedly issued on Tuesday evening.

The teacher went on to reveal that the students had written the threats on the walls of the toilets, an issue that drew curiosity amongst the other students who then reported the matter to the administration,

Siaya County Director of Education Nelson Sifuna confirmed that the internal mock exams which were supposed to be done on Monday, December 6 were suspended and the students were sent home indefinitely.

The school was in the headlines again following a Sunday morning fire that razed a 630-capacity Boaz Owino dormitory complex which hosts the Form One students, destroying property of unknown value.

headline: Chiloba Shuts Down Nairobi-Based Radio Station
author: By Marvin Chege

breadcrumbs.name: Chiloba Shuts Down Nairobi-Based Radio Station

description: The CA found that the station was operating from a residential building at Puma Court, Tena Estate which sits next to the popular Umoja Estate in the city
articleBody:
The Communications Authority of Kenya (CA) has ordered the shutdown of Gituamba FM, a radio station that has been operating in Nairobi illegally.

In its statement by CA Director-General Ezra Chiloba on Tuesday, December 7, the CA found that the station was operating from a residential building at Puma Court, Tena Estate which sits next to the popular Umoja Estate in the city.

Gituamba FM was found to be broadcasting without a licence from the authority, contrary to the Kenya Information and Communications Act, 1998 (KICA).

CA also reported that the station’s owner was arrested and will be processed in court to be charged with setting up a radio station without proper licensing.

“During the operation, the station’s owner, one Mr Nelson Githinji Ndegwa was arrested. He will be arraigned in court and charged with the establishment of a radio communication station without a valid licence, contrary to Sections 35(2), 46C and 46Q of the KICA.

“The suspect is currently in custody at the Buruburu Police station, Nairobi, awaiting presentation in court,” read the statement by CA in part.

It added that operating an illegal radio station may cause interference of licensed broadcasters, compromising the quality of broadcasting services available to consumers.

“Anyone wishing to provide information and communication services in the country must ensure they obtain appropriate licences from the authority without fail,” added the statement.

The CA, under Chiloba’s administration, has been hard at work weeding out the irregularities dogging the Kenyan media space as the country inches closer to the 2022 General Elections.

At any given election period, media houses, with the inclusion of new media in recent years, have been showing off their real talents and capabilities in giving Kenyans minute-by-minute updates regarding the polls, known to bring the country to a grinding halt.

The CA on Saturday, December 4, shut down Sasa TV.

Neno Evangelism Centre in which Sasa TV operates under was ordered to stop airing live programmes for six months, effective immediately.

“The Communications Authority of Kenya has directed M/S Neno Evangelism Centre, a broadcaster operating as SASA TV, to stop airing live programming with immediate effect. This directive shall be observed for a period of six months,” read the CA’s statement in part at the time.

Sasa TV was directed to ensure that it has adequate and qualified personnel duly accredited by the Media Council of Kenya (MCK).

The Authority also directed the broadcaster to ensure that staff undergo mandatory training on appropriate operations of the Profanity Delay Mechanism system, management of live broadcasts, broadcasting legal framework, consumer protection, and complaints handling.

The MCK had raised an alarm towards the station on Thursday, October 28 after it provided him with the platform to address not just his church audience but to his TV audiences who were watching from home.

It was referring to a video clip that went viral on social media on Sunday, October 9 where he warned Kenyan nurses against groping his private parts in the event of his death.

headline: Car Wash Attendant Latest Omoka Na Moti Winner
author: Marvin Chege

breadcrumbs.name: Car Wash Attendant Latest Omoka Na Moti Winner

description: The 23-year-old car wash attendant from Ruaraka correctly predicted seven games on Thursday, December 2
articleBody:
After seven months of cleaning cars, Jurgens Luchesi Shisakha will finally make his dream of owning and dusting his own car a reality after becoming the second winner of Mozzart Bet’s Omoka na Moti promotion.

The 23-year-old car wash attendant from Ruaraka correctly predicted seven games on Thursday, December 2 that had combined odds of 2210 fetching him Ksh88,000 on top of the car.

Luchesi revealed that when he placed the bet he failed to follow up on the games and had to pick his jaws from the floor when he received news of winning the brand new Proton Saga.

“This was pure luck and I thank God for winning the car, it was a very big surprise, nobody knows about this even my girlfriend still doesn’t know but I plan on surprising her with the news,”

“Before I got the call, I spoke to my mother and I assured her that I would send her some cash. Then a few minutes later I got a call from Mozzart Bet informing me of the news, I didn’t even tell anyone because I was in shock,” explained Luchesi.

Aside from working in a car wash, he also supplements his income with a number of odd jobs such as assisting his cousin who runs a kiosk in the slums of Mathare.

Form ndio hii @Mozzartbetkenya is taking the game to another level this December.There are 31 cars to be won,1 car per day. One of the car winners will take away,a 2-bedroomed house in Kileleshwa estate in Nairobi. Wekelea hio bet https://t.co/OdKW2CdaoK 😎 #OmokaNaMoti

— 𝐌𝐭𝐮 𝐉𝐮𝐠🎅🍺 (@WayneOdera) December 3, 2021

The ardent Chelsea and Kakamega Homeboyz fan is yet to join University after clearing High School back in 2018 but has added acquiring a degree in Urban and Physical planning as part of his 2022 new year resolution.

Luchesi learned about the Omoka na Moti promotion while watching Tales of Crazy Kennar on YouTube with the advert popping thrice and he decided to log onto Mozzart Bet to get more information.

Asked about his betting secret, the punter revealed that consistency is the name of the game as he has been betting for three years.

“I ’ve been betting since 2018 so I know most teams that I bet on because I usually bet continuously, I cannot really remember my biggest win prior to this because I had won many and also lost on a number of occasions,”

“The secret to betting is consistency, if you know Manchester United are performing poorly and Arsenal have been on a good run, it makes it easier to place a more informed bet. You cannot go for three months without betting and expect to win, ” noted Luchesi.

The car wash attendant has already spent Ksh30,000 of his Ksh80,000 loot on settling debts and catering for his rent and plans to expound his chicken farm back in Mumias.

“I want to take it to our home in Mumias for it to be blessed then get a driving license, maybe get a driver before acquiring my legal documents,” concluded Luchesi.

There are still 29 cars up for grabs with Mozzart Bet will awarding one vehicle every day in December 2021 to one punter whose multi-bet ticket has the highest accumulation of odds on a minimum fifty bob stake.

headline: Citizen TV Journalist Loses Ksh50K After Arsenal Beaten By Man United
author: Marvin Chege

breadcrumbs.name: Citizen TV Journalist Loses Ksh50K After Arsenal Beaten By Man United

description: He took to Facebook to reveal his sentiments while questioning how Arsenal disappointed him that night.
articleBody:
A Citizen TV journalist lost a Ksh50,000 bet after Arsenal were defeated 3-2 to age-old rivals Manchester United in a Premier League midweek encounter at Old Trafford on Thursday, December 2.

Senior reporter Stephen Letoo is an avid Arsenal supporter and had made a bet with a friend on the match, known for bringing Kenya to a halt as a majority of the nation’s football fans support the two teams.

He took to Facebook to reveal his sentiments while questioning how Arsenal disappointed him that night.

“Last night I lost a Ksh50,000 Manchester United Vs Arsenal bet to Grand Mullah Kaizer. Why Arsenal? Why?” he wondered.

Letoo had initially shared that the Gunners would confidently beat the Red Devils, who before the Thursday match had an unbeaten run that stretched to as far back as April 2018, during Arsene Wenger’s final weeks in charge.

“Every Arsenal game has been a must-win since we beat that zebra crossing team. Wekea Arsenal kichwa kisha ulalae (just bet on Arsenal to win and then go to sleep),” he advised.

Kazier had confirmed the bet while laughing at the reporter for preempting victory before the real match.

The game was initially all Arsenal’s in terms of play and they took the lead through Emile Smith Rowe in bizarre circumstances after just 13 minutes. He fired from outside the box while United goalkeeper David De Gea lay injured in the penalty area, having been trod on by his teammate Fred.

United were however level on 44 minutes when Jadon Sancho picked out Fred in the box, who in turn laid off the ball to Bruno Fernandes to sweep home.

Marcus Rashford had the opportunity to turn the game around for United but his effort was denied by Arsenal goalkeeper Aaron Ramsdale. However, United went 2-1 up two minutes later with Rashford setting up Cristiano Ronaldo to score his 800th career goal.

The Gunners then set up a frenetic second half with Martin Odegaard firing past De Gea to level it at 2-2 within 120 seconds, but Ronaldo had the final say with a 70th-minute winner from the penalty spot after Odegaard fouled Fred.

The victory in the league table. Arsenal remained fifth, two points ahead of their opponents.

Their interim head coach Michael Carrick announced after the match that he would leave the club after guiding them to a Champions League win against Villareal and a draw against league leaders Chelsea. German coach Ralf Rangnick took over after the club sacked Ole Gunnar Solskjaer.

headline: Sprinter Omanyala Joins Kenya Police
author: By Marvin Chege
description: Omanyala will join the force's General Service Unit's (GSU) elite Recce Squad division.
articleBody:
Kenyan sprinter Ferdinand Omanyala Omurwa has joined the National Police Service (NPS).

Viral Tea has learnt that he will join the force’s General Service Unit’s (GSU) elite Recce Squad division.

The sprinter is expected to commence his duties in January but will avoid having to go to the Kiganjo Police Training College (KPTC) for training.

The 25-year-old athlete, in a statement by the NPS, has taken up a new role that will see him represent the National Police Service and the country in future track events.

Omanyala was briefed on his new role on Friday morning, December 3 when he called on Inspector General Hilary Mutyambai at his Jogoo House office. Present to witness his induction was the Dean of Students University of Nairobi Johnson Kinyua and the Student Union (UNSA) Head of Communication, Joshua Sirma.

He joins a pool of other elite athletes in the NPS including the likes of David Rudisha, Joshua Kamworor, Vivian Cheruiyot, Julius Yego and the legendary Ezekiel Kemboi, among others.

Speaking at the brief ceremony, Omanyala thanked the National Police Service and the Government for supporting talent and he promised to repay this kindness with success in the track events.

“It is an honour to serve the National Police Service and I promise to give my best as an athlete. I also understand that there is life after sprinting,” he praised.

The IG urged Omanyala to maintain his sporting discipline for him to utilise his full potential and at the same time deliver on his new role as a Police athlete.

“I wish you well in the service for your country,” the IG concluded as he invited him for an official briefing.

Omanyala, a second-year Bachelor of Science student at the University of Nairobi rose to stardom in Lagos Nigeria where he clocked 10.01 seconds on March 30, 2021, at an athletic event dubbed the ‘Making of Champions (MOC) Grand Prix’ where he met the qualification for the Tokyo 2020 Olympic Games.

Viral Tea has learnt that he will join the force’s General Service Unit’s (GSU) elite Recce Squad division.

articleBody:
Lady luck smiled at a Rongai man on the first day of December 2021 as his fifty-shilling bet won him a Ksh1.2 million Car in Mozzartbet ’s Omoka na Moti Promotion, the biggest prize promotion in the betting landscape of Kenya.

Zadock Sanawa, a civil engineer who has been jobless since the advent of Covid-19 last year, met the bare minimum qualification for the competition eligibility to become the life-changing promotion’s first winner. Thirty more winners are set to be rewarded in the festive month.

The car is in addition to the successful Ksh20,827 ticket of his fourteen-game multi-bet.

Sanawa’s name has also been drafted into a privileged draw of 31 individuals eligible for an apartment in Kileleshwa at the end of the promotion.

“I’m very happy about it. I don’t know what to say. I bet regularly and I win small amounts here and there but this is awesome. We discussed and I told them my bet was successful but I had not been contacted by Mozzartbet so I did not know about it. I thought someone else was the winner,” an elated Sanawa said

As the old adage, fortune knocks once at every man’s door, goes Sanawa has fate to thank for his huge win as his bet did not have the highest accumulations of odds on 1 st December 2021.

A number of punters had higher odds on their multi-bet tickets but failed to meet the minimum requirements for the Omoka na Moti Promotion.

headline: DPP Haji May Have Hinted At His Favourite Football Team (VIDEO)
author: By Marvin Chege

breadcrumbs.name: DPP Haji May Have Hinted At His Favourite Football Team (VIDEO)

description: (19) Speaking to KBC on Wednesday, November 24, Haji had expressed his love for the English Premier League (EPL), touted as the world’s biggest and best football league. The Director of Public Prosecution (DPP) Noordin Haji may have teased his favourite football team while revealing his love for the sport in favour of other sports • Read More »
articleBody:
Speaking to KBC on Wednesday, November 24, Haji had expressed his love for the English Premier League (EPL), touted as the world’s biggest and best football league.

The Director of Public Prosecution (DPP) Noordin Haji may have teased his favourite football team while revealing his love for the sport in favour of other sports such as golf.

Speaking to KBC on Wednesday, November 24, Haji had expressed his love for the English Premier League (EPL), touted as the world’s biggest and best football league.

When asked about his favourite football team, the DPP played cagey with his team of choice, noting that it was neither Arsenal nor Manchester United, two clubs which are popular amongst Kenyans for many years.

A Manchester United vs Arsenal match during the 2020/21 Premier League season. /FUTAA

“I do play football but I am not a die-hard fan either. My team is currently performing badly but we are praying,” he stated as he burst into laughter.

Based on current form, Manchester United have been on a poor run domestically, with a win, a draw and four defeats in the last six games. Arsenal, in contrast, have been on a resurgence having registered two draws and three wins before their thumping 4-0 loss to Liverpool.

United then responded to their latest 4-1 battering by Watford by sacking Ole Gunnar Solskjaer almost a day later. Michael Carrick took charge of the club’s 2-0 win at Villareal in the UEFA Champions League.

They face their season’s toughest test when they travel to table-topping Chelsea on Sunday, November 28, who ran riot in a 4-0 win against Juventus on Tuesday, November 23 before hosting the Gunners in a midweek clash on Tuesday, December 2.

Meanwhile Haji disclosed that he did not have any affiliations to golf while growing up. Golf is a sport that is associated with the elite in class as well as senior government officials and at some point, former President Mwai Kibaki was a big fan of golf.

Haji shot down the sport in amusement by stating that it involved grown-ups running after a small ball and that he would rather play football at home.

“I don’t play golf because I am an ordinary person. Chasing a small ball as a grown-up? I would rather stay at home and play football there.

“You know I learned in Nyahururu DEB primary, so I am just an ordinary person. So those things of golf I do not know. I usually watch it on TV and I wonder why grown-ups would follow such a small ball. Football has a bigger ball,” he revealed.

He added that he prefers playing football during his free time and picked swimming in favour of golf.

“I would prefer playing football or swimming. Golf? Aiiiiiiii,” he replied.

In terms of his time as Director of Public Prosecution (DPP), he stated that he has a term to finish up, but he assured that he is ready to leave office if found of incompetence and will do so gracefully.

“If the President sets up a tribunal and the tribunal finds that I have to leave, I am a man of God and believe that God has better plans for me. If PSC feels that I have to go, I cannot be in this seat forever. I recognize that, that’s why I have a term and the term will end,” he noted.

headline: Detectives Uncover Wedding Plans Of Man Who Killed BBC Journalist
author: Marvin Chege

breadcrumbs.name: Detectives Uncover Wedding Plans Of Man Who Killed BBC Journalist

description: (4) The details have pointed out that the suspect was engaged and on the verge of marrying his girlfriend in December this year Fresh details regarding the murder of BBC journalist Kate Mitchell have revealed the wedding and engagement plans of the prime suspect implicated in the murder at a hotel in Westlands, Nairobi on • Read More »
articleBody:
The details have pointed out that the suspect was engaged and on the verge of marrying his girlfriend in December this year

Fresh details regarding the murder of BBC journalist Kate Mitchell have revealed the wedding and engagement plans of the prime suspect implicated in the murder at a hotel in Westlands, Nairobi on Friday, November 19.

The details have pointed out that the suspect was engaged and on the verge of marrying his girlfriend in December this year, plans that did not materialise after he allegedly jumped to his death from the eighth floor, where Mitchell had booked a room in the hotel.

He had booked a room on the seventh floor with his fiancée on the same building, a matter which has puzzled detectives.

His fiancée had patiently waited for her boyfriend, who left her in their hotel room as he went to the bar briefly. She kept waiting for he boyfriend the whole night but did not show up.

DCI detectives at a crime scene. /FILE

As she waited for him, the suspect followed the BBC manager and entered her room, a different room on the upper floor of the hotel, where the confrontation took place. He is said to have jumped from the hotel after the confrontation, dying on the spot.

Meanwhile, Mitchell was found dead inside her room.

Reports indicated that Mitchell’s room was locked with a chain lock from inside and that the security officers had to call the hotel’s technician, who opened the door using a screwdriver.

On finding her lying down in the bathroom, they dialled paramedics who arrived at the scene and confirmed that Mitchell was dead and observed a stab wound on the left side of her neck and bruises around her eyes.

“We suspect that this is when the two engaged in a scuffle that resulted in the death of Mitchell, who after realising things were getting out of control, pressed the room’s alarm. This must have spooked the suspect, who, forgetting they were on the eighth floor, jumped out of the window and died,” the police revealed to the Nation.

The hotel’s management also called the police, who found that the window of the room was broken.

“Upon checking what may have happened, another body was discovered on the first floor,” part of the police report reads.

Meanwhile, as the events unravelled, the fiancée grew worried about the suspect’s whereabouts and had only learnt of the matter at the Kilimani Police Station when she was picked by detectives to record a statement.

headline: Win Brand New Car And Kileleshwa Apartment For Christmas With Ksh50
author: Marvin Chege

breadcrumbs.name: Win Brand New Car And Kileleshwa Apartment For Christmas With Ksh50

description: The month-long festival dubbed ‘Omoka na Moti’ will reward one punter who accumulates the biggest winning odds in a single multi-bet ticket.
articleBody:
Leading betting firm Mozzart Bet has launched undisputedly the biggest ever promotion in the betting landscape of Kenya by putting out for grabs thirty one brand new cars – one for each day of December 2021 – and one posh apartment in the affluent suburbs of Kileleshwa to crown the promotion.

The month-long festival dubbed ‘Omoka na Moti’ will reward one punter who accumulates the biggest winning odds in a single multi-bet ticket.

Punters can start revving off with brand new cars from the first day to December 31, 2021. The super luckiest winner whose ticket will have the biggest odds among the daily winners in the month will get the crown jewel – an apartment in Kileleshwa.

The promotion which turns each December day into a Christmas Day has been shown the green lights by Kenya’s scrupulous regulators Betting Control and Licensing Board (BCLB).

A festival like no other, the promotion is only limited to registered gamers on Mozzartbet.co.ke. The company will make daily announcements of winners through the official press while the ultimate winner will receive the title and keys to the Kileleshwa apartment in January.

Mozzart Marketing Manager Frank Ochieng challenged gamers to play for more than just daily winnings and aim for the ultimate prize

“This is an interesting promotion and we are happy to reward our customers daily during this festive season. At the end of it all one of them will win the ultimate prize of a beautiful apartment in upmarket Nairobi. It can be anyone so my rallying call to the punters is to keep playing on www.mozzartbet.co.ke,” he said.

Promotion duration: from 1.12.2021 (00:01 h) to 31.12.2021 (23:59 h)

DAILY PRIZE: The winner of the daily prize i.e. the car, is one participant daily who will have won a multi-bet with the highest total winning odds for that day of December, during the promotion. This means the multi-bet must be won in order to qualify for the promotion.

GRAND PRIZE: On top of the CAR, at the end of December 2021

Mozzart bet will also reward only 1 out of the 31 winners who will have attained the highest total winning odds (best-winning ticket out of the 31) with an Apartment in Nairobi.

Place a multi-bet of a minimum of 4 games.

The minimum stake on your Multi-bet must be Ksh50.

If a sporting event in your multi-bet is cancelled for any reason, odds of 1 are calculated for that event, but the multi-bet still participates in the prize game, but that sporting event is not taken into account for calculation.

In the event that the kick-off of a sporting event is postponed, the ticket still participates in the promotion but will wait a maximum of 50 hours to confirm the outcome of the event.

In case that two or more participants have the same total winning odds, the participant who paid the multi-bet first has the advantage.

All events on the Bet-slip must be sports events (results of individual or group sports events, a certain event during a sports competition, etc.)

Live Bet tickets, JP tickets, my number, Lucky super 6 and Virtual tickets do not qualify.

The beginning of all sports events on the ticket must not be earlier than 00:01, December 1st, 2021. Otherwise, the ticket is not taken into account. I.e., it does not meet the conditions for participation in the promotion.

All bet slips must be from that promotional day. The beginning of the last sports event that is on the bet slip must be no later than 11:59 PM on the day when the bet slip was played. Bet slips that have matches from several promotional days are not included in the promotion.

One customer can only win one daily prize during the promotion and will be in consideration for the grand prize also.

Each player can play an unlimited number of tickets during the period of the promotion.

headline: I Would Post My Man Online If I Was Married- Joey Muthengi
author: Marvin Chege

breadcrumbs.name: I Would Post My Man Online If I Was Married- Joey Muthengi

description: (13) Muthengi added that she would not shy away from posting her husband on social media and would not fear doing so over and over until her followers would be irked to the point of asking her to stop. Media personality and former Capital FM radio host Joey Muthengi has affirmed that she is not • Read More »
articleBody:
Muthengi added that she would not shy away from posting her husband on social media and would not fear doing so over and over until her followers would be irked to the point of asking her to stop.

Media personality and former Capital FM radio host Joey Muthengi has affirmed that she is not married.

Taking to her Instagram page on Tuesday, November 23, Muthengi revealed that she was prompted to dismiss the claims that she had tied the knot after rumours went round that she was hiding her husband from her followers.

She added that she would not shy away from posting her husband on social media and would not fear doing so over and over until her followers would be irked to the point of asking her to stop.

Media personality Joey Muthengi during an interview on NTV. /INSTAGRAM

“I’m not married…you think I would be married and then I’m just hiding a whole husband from Instagram?

“If I was married, I will be so proud of that man and he will be all over my page. I will be one of those people who you are annoyed by, you will be like can this chick stop posting her husband, so am definitely not married,” said Joey Muthengi.

The 36-year-old clarified the rumours for the second time in 2021. Back in March, she revealed that she was not literal about getting married and had only joked about it during an afternoon radio show where she was invited as a guest.

She appealed to her followers to move on and desist from using threats.

“I jokingly said that I will never get married. This was on an afternoon radio show of which I had been invited as a guest. Can we please move on and not use threats against me/us?” tweeted Joey Muthengi.

Many of her fans have been flooding her messages with the million-dollar question on when she would tie the knot, given the achievements and major strides she has made in her media career as well as the success from the fruits of her labour.

Muthengi, as many would recall, left Capital FM on December 11, 2020. She was hosting The Jam drive show alongside Martin Kariuki from 3 pm to 7 pm and has since been replaced by June Gachui in a wave of changes announced at the station.

The rumours could have also surfaced from the string of celebrities and media personalities tying the knot in lush weddings, the latest being former Inooro TV presenter Muthoni wa Mukiri, who married her longtime lover Isaac Njoroge in a private ceremony held at the Windsor Country Club on Saturday, November 20.

, where she flaunted a diamond ring, an indication that her boyfriend had proposed.

headline: KBC Announce Twins As Badi Muhsin’s Replacement (VIDEO)
author: Marvin Chege

breadcrumbs.name: KBC Announce Twins As Badi Muhsin’s Replacement (VIDEO)

description: (7) They will present the Dira ya Magwiji bulletin every Saturday from 7 pm alongside Pauline Sheghu, whom they will be alternating. Identical twins Jamila and Wanjiru Mbugua have returned to the media industry as prime time news anchors at the Kenya Broadcasting Corporation (KBC), replacing the late Badi Muhsin. Muhsin passed away on Friday, • Read More »
articleBody:
They will present the Dira ya Magwiji bulletin every Saturday from 7 pm alongside Pauline Sheghu, whom they will be alternating.

Identical twins Jamila and Wanjiru Mbugua have returned to the media industry as prime time news anchors at the Kenya Broadcasting Corporation (KBC), replacing the late Badi Muhsin.

Muhsin passed away on Friday, October 8, 2021, after battling a short illness.

They will present the Dira ya Magwiji bulletin every Saturday from 7 pm alongside Pauline Sheghu, whom they will be alternating.

The late veteran KBC anchor Badi Muhsin. /KBC DIGITAL

Jamila had worked at NTV, hosting the Property Show while Wanjiru, her twin sister, served as a communication and marketing consultant at Diamond Media.

Wanjiru worked as a business news anchor at KBC from 2006-2008.

Jamila was a host at K24 TV before she moved to Nation Media Group. During her time at the Mediamax station, she hosted the Faraja show.

Muhsin had in 2020 made a comeback at the station which spruced itself up in terms of brand and journalists this year. It was the same 2020 that saw him undergo surgery for treatment of kidney stones.

He graced the screens alongside Tom Mboya, Catherine Kasavuli, Cynthia Nyamai, Pauline Sheghu, John Kioria and Fayaz Kureish.

Muhsin worked for the national broadcaster during the Late President Daniel Moi’s era from 1980 and retired in 2002.

He put his best foot forward with the national broadcaster and showed immense character in broadcast journalism.

“You have to be willing to learn and prove yourself. You also have to be highly disciplined as your work puts you in the public limelight and your behaviour, at work at outside, reflects on your station,” Badi stated in an interview with Parents Magazine.

KBC Editor-in-Chief Samuel Maina stated during the new-look unveiling that the changes have been informed by the market dynamics and changing audience needs.

“The ‘Legends’ is only on Saturday at 7pm and 9pm. The market has been yearning for these anchors. The Corporation decided to give them an opportunity to deliver our product to Kenyans.

“They are also very experienced and will also be training our upcoming anchors to sharpen their anchoring skills,” Maina said ahead of the relaunch.

Maina added that new technologies had been injected for quality broadcasting, adding that KBC “invested a lot in software and hardware, a modern television anchoring set, and as such we will fully start broadcasting on High-Definition technology unlike before where we used to combine HD and SD.”

The KBC anchors presenting the 9 pm news who were announced on June 21, 2021. /KBC DIGITAL

Reports indicated that the two had a heated argument that turned ugly • Read More »
articleBody:
“We send our deepest condolences to her family and her many friends around the world,” she noted.

Initial investigations have since indicated that she was strangled to death by a man she was with inside her hotel room after an alleged altercation.

Reports indicated that the two had a heated argument that turned ugly when Kate tried to press the alarm bell, but she was strangled before she could receive any help.

Nairobi Regional Police Commander Benjamin Nthumbi revealed that her hotel room was locked from inside when detectives arrived. They found her body inside the room and noticed some shards of a broken window on the floor.

“Upon checking through the window, the detectives saw a man’s body lying on the ground. He was later identified as the man Mitchell had been seen with earlier.

“The man had jumped off the eighth floor of the hotel through the room’s window,” said Nthumbi.

He added that investigations were ongoing to determine the cause of Kate’s death.

Mitchell worked at the BBC Media Action, which is the BBC’s international development charity.

“I am so sorry to inform you of the death of our colleague from BBC Media Action Kate Mitchell. She was in Nairobi and died in her hotel yesterday.

“Kate worked with so many people over the past 14 years, particularly in Zambia, South Sudan and most recently in Ethiopia. This news will be incredibly difficult for all of us, and especially for those teams who worked closely with Kate,” an internal email sent to BBC staff read in part.

headline: Jamhuri Day: Trooping of Colour Explained
author: By Linah Mwangi

breadcrumbs.name: Jamhuri Day: Trooping of Colour Explained

description: This tradition started with the Royal family in England in the 17th century.
articleBody:
Kenya marked the 58th Jamhuri Day celebrations on Sunday, December 12 at the Uhuru Gardens, Nairobi.

One thing that stood out during the celebrations was the Trooping of the colour.

What is trooping of the colour?

This tradition started with the Royal family in England in the 17th century. Upon the arrival of The Queen at Horse Guard’s Parade in Whitehall, she is greeted by a Royal salute.

She then carries out an inspection of the troops, who are fully trained and operational soldiers wearing the ceremonial uniform of red tunics and bearskin hats.

The colors are the highest honor for any regiment or unit and are well-guarded and treasured. Losing the colours leads to the disbandment of the regiment or unit. All infantry units and bases are presented with both presidential and regimental colours.

Normally, a presidential color is trooped when a unit or base performs in a national ceremony, or a foreign head of state is honored with the honor guard.

Anglican and Catholic Bishops and Muslim Kadhi lead in the consecration service of the 19th Battalion, the Kenya Rifles, Presidential and Regimental Colours at Uhuru Gardens during the 2021 Jamhuri Day celebrations. pic.twitter.com/tOzZ2W3B2H

— Kenya Defence Forces (@kdfinfo) December 12, 2021

Both presidential and regimental colors are carried by a commissioned officer and escorted by two armed senior non-commissioned officers.

There is a strict drill for marching in and out and handling the presidential and regimental colours.

The colours are always kept under lock and key and only removed occasionally for ceremonial displays.

During Trooping of the colours, the colours are marched under the escort of the colour party to the edge of the parade.

His Excellency the President of the Republic of Kenya and Commander-in-Chief of the Defence Forces Hon Uhuru Kenyatta presents the 19 KR Presidential and Regimental Colours to Colour Officers at Uhuru Gardens during the 2021 Jamhuri Day celebrations. pic.twitter.com/zpbkzhRIzK

— Kenya Defence Forces (@kdfinfo) December 12, 2021

The colour officer is of the rank of a Lieutenant and commands the colour party.

After being accorded the national honors, the troops paraded the colours. The parade formally receives the colour and then troops the colours before the commander-in-chief in slow and quick time.

During Trooping, every soldier on parade has a close view of the colour as it passes whilst paying the highest possible honor by presenting arms in salute.

According to the military tradition, the whole ceremony is a symbolic trust given to a unit/base.

headline: Kenyan Women Shopping On Instagram Warned Ahead Of Festive Season
author: Marvin Chege

breadcrumbs.name: Kenyan Women Shopping On Instagram Warned Ahead Of Festive Season

description: Many online shopping platforms are gearing up for what will be one of the highest activities every year
articleBody:
The Directorate of Criminal Investigations (DCI) has sent a warning to Kenyans shopping through online means as cases of fraud are expected to go up with the influx of activity ahead of the festive season.

Many online shopping platforms are gearing up for what will be one of the highest activities every year as Kenyans splash their cash on various household items to prepare for the Christmas period.

Kenyans especially seeking new household items without having to leave their houses are trooping to e-commerce platforms and using online payments to acquire their goods, but with that comes the danger of online scammers.

The DCI in their statement on Monday, December 6 advised Kenyans to exercise caution when shopping for their preferred goods and products online.

It gave scenarios whereby several clients have reported ordering for goods advertised on social media, especially Instagram which is very popular amongst women countrywide.

Upon delivery of the goods, they discover to their dismay that they were of different quality to the one advertised.

“As we approach the festive season, members of the public are advised to be careful when shopping for goods online.

We have received numerous reports from clients who ordered for goods advertised on social networking sites especially on Instagram, but the goods were either not delivered or the quality not similar to what was advertised,” the DCI stated in part.

The detectives added that many Kenyan women have fallen victim to such fraud syndicates given that they flock to the platform to shop for the latest cosmetics, trendy outfits and jewellery.

“Many Kenyans especially ladies shopping for trendy outfits and jewellery, have fallen victim and lost their money through such frauds,” they revealed.

The detectives advised Kenyans to be watchful when buying goods online by doing cross-checks on the name of the seller and their address.

It also sounded an alarm of a growing trend whereby fraudsters masquerade as websites belonging to established vendors and advised them to only shop from verified retailers.

“You are advised to be careful when making purchases online, by first ascertaining the identity of the seller and the address of their businesses.

“Resist the temptation to send money to perceived genuine dealers, who later turn out to be cons,” they advised.

The DCI in September listed seven scams Kenyans should be on high alert for. They include:

Online groups luring jobless Kenyan youth on promises of getting them jobs within and abroad,
Online product vendors who disappear once payments are done in advance,
Online car hires that never materialize.
Online cash traders (Forex Exchange)
Social media sites bearing prominent people’s profiles aimed at misleading and extortion,
Fraudsters making random calls while posing as service providers to cause panic to unsuspecting victims, informing them of possible security breaches to their Bank & Mpesa accounts hence end up revealing their confidential particulars,
Agencies/Individuals advertising non-existing Rental Houses and/or Plots for sale, who ask for deposits while faking high demands after which they lie low on the victims.

“Pursuit of these criminals is in most instances a lengthy procedure calling for Cyber-Forensic Interventions, mostly because perpetrators use different social media/SIM Cards to contact different people, after which they block & delete their accounts upon successful transactions,” the sleuths stated in part at the time.

They urged the public to always and immediately report to their nearest Police Stations any time they lose their ID Cards, sim cards or mobile phones and laptops, personal documents including academic testimonials and driving licenses, and to obtain abstract forms thereby issued.

headline: Revealed: Why IG Mutyambai Skipped His Weekly Twitter Chat
author: By Marvin Chege

breadcrumbs.name: Revealed: Why IG Mutyambai Skipped His Weekly Twitter Chat

description: Through the #EngageTheIG forum, he has grown closer to Kenyans in a globalised world, addressed their burning issues and concerns especially regarding the minor and major security issues across the country.
articleBody:
Inspector-General (IG) of Police Hilary Mutyambai is a man who has rarely missed his weekly engagement with Kenyans that takes place every Monday from 11 am on Twitter, which lasts for only one hour.

Through the #EngageTheIG forum, he has grown closer to Kenyans in a globalised world, addressed their burning issues and concerns especially regarding the minor and major security issues across the country.

He has managed to use the forum to make key directives that have helped bolster security amongst members of the public, other times the directives have helped solve matters of public interest.

“There has been a clamour by the public to have a closer and keener engagement with @NPSOfficial_KE. I have taken note of that and will be dedicating an hour every alternate Monday to engage with you personally on a live Twitter chat #EngageTheIG,” Mutyambai said in June 2020.

However, on Monday, December 6, he was absent for one of the sessions, which raised curiosity amongst Kenyans seeking answers on security matters as the country heads to the festive season whereby insecurity issues are known to spike.

Taking to his official Twitter handle, Mutyambai explained that he had to postpone the weekly forum to a later date.

There has been a clamor by the public to have a closer and keener engagement with @NPSOfficial_KE. I have taken note of that and will be dedicating an hour every alternate Monday to engage with you personally on a live Twitter chat #EngageTheIG. pic.twitter.com/hv6OSUoxPw

— Hilary N. Mutyambai, MGH, nsc (AU). (@IG_NPS) June 21, 2020

“Due to national engagement, #EngageTheIG has been postponed to a later date,” Mutyambai wrote.

A statement by the National Police Service (NPS) revealed that he is currently presiding over the Recruits Passing Out Rehearsals at the National Police College Embakasi B Campus.

He was received to the College by DIG-Kenya Police Service Edward N. Mbugua and the General Service Unit (GSU) Commandant Mr Douglas K. Kirocho, Senior Assistant Inspector General of Police.

Mutyambai’s absence from the platform has left questions fielded by Kenyans on Twitter (KOT) unanswered, given that his son, David Mwendwa, surrendered himself to the Lang’ata police station on Friday night, December 3 after a road accident along the Southern Bypass in Nairobi left two dead.

Mwendwa turned himself in following claims that went rife that the police were covering up the accident to exonerate him. However, Nairobi Traffic Police Commander, Joshua Omukata, refuted the claims and maintained that investigations would be carried out irrespective of blood relations.

“That he is the son of the Inspector General is not a fact to this matter. Even if he is the son of the IG or not the son of the IG the thing ahead of us is an accident.

“We are not investigating the son of who but we are investigating an accident in which we have the driver. It’s about the person who has committed the accident not any other person,” Omukata told the media.

Medical investigations would also be carried out to ascertain whether or not Mwendwa was drunk after he allegedly hit and fatally injured two people on Thursday, December 2. The two were a motorcyclist and his pillion passenger.

articleBody:
A Twitter user on Sunday, December 5 poked holes at Machakos Governor Alfred Mutua’s condolence message to the veteran artist and cultural archivist Alan Donovan who died earlier in the day.

Mutua had taken to the platform to mourn Donovan as a lover of arts and an environmentalist who resided in Mlolongo, Machakos County at the time of his passing.

“It is with great sadness that I pass my condolences to the family of Alan Donovan, a great Pioneer of the arts.

“He passed away this morning at his home in Mlolongo, Machakos County. From African Heritage to protection of the environment. Donovan was a force that touched lives,” he wrote.

It with great sadness that I pass my condolences to the family of Alan Donovan, a great pioneer of the arts. He passed away this morning at his home in Mlolongo, Machakos County. From African Heritage to protection of the environment, Donovan was a force that touched lives. RIP. pic.twitter.com/WFXlZUDgkE

— Dr. Alfred Mutua (@DrAlfredMutua) December 5, 2021

The user named Tim Njiru caught wind of the message and replied to it by exposing how the county boss had allegedly ruined the life of the deceased.

He claimed that Mutua wanted some of his properties and shamed him for being hypocritical given that he had played a part in accelerating his woes.

“I’m sorry Alfred, but in my last moments and conversations with Mr Donovan, you didn’t feature as a very good man. Alan told me, you wanted the land where the African Heritage house sits on and its surroundings.

“You made his life a living hell. Don’t get me started,” he responded.

I’m sorry Alfred, but in my last moments and conversations with Mr Donovan, you didn’t feature as a very good man. Alan told me, you wanted the land where the African Heritage house sits on and its surroundings. You made his life a living hell. Don’t get me started. https://t.co/rjG3tYFqzg

— Tim Njiru (@timnjiru) December 5, 2021

The tweet ignited various reactions from Kenyans to the point that Governor Mutua had to hide the tweet. Spot checks by Viral Tea indicate that Mutua’s message stood as of Monday, December 6.

African Heritage Estates manager Tom Otieno revealed to the Business Daily that Donovan died peacefully in his sleep at his home in Athi River.

He came to Kenya more than 50 years ago and would play a key role in Kenya’s cultural affairs as well as those of Africa by collecting art and preserving the continent’s heritage.

Alongside Kenya’s first vice president, Donovan founded both the African Heritage Gallery and birthed the African Heritage House, which sits on eight acres of land overlooking the Nairobi National Park.

It is the most photographed house in Africa and the first house in the continent to be featured in the prestigious US Architectural Digest in November 1996.

headline: Block Sonko From Social Media- Esther Passaris to DCI
author: By Marvin Chege

breadcrumbs.name: Block Sonko From Social Media- Esther Passaris to DCI

description: (14) Passaris faulted Sonko’s actions in dragging Governor Ann Kananu, his former lawyer Cecil Miller and High Court Judge Said Chitembwe into the riveting video leaks. Nairobi Woman Representative Esther Passaris has appealed to the Directorate of Criminal Investigations (DCI) to block former Governor Mike Sonko’s social media accounts in response to his expose that • Read More »
articleBody:
Nairobi Woman Representative Esther Passaris has appealed to the Directorate of Criminal Investigations (DCI) to block former Governor Mike Sonko’s social media accounts in response to his expose that rocked the whole country.

Speaking on Tuesday night during the illumination of the Kenyatta International Convention Centre (KICC) to mark the beginning of the 16 days of activism against gender-based violence (GBV), Passaris faulted Sonko’s actions in dragging Governor Ann Kananu, his former lawyer Cecil Miller and High Court Judge Said Chitembwe into the riveting video leaks.

The expose also featured a woman, Merry Nkatha, who narrated in a press conference how she was coerced by the former governor to implicate several people for which in return, she was promised a whooping Ksh20 million.

Merry Nkatha, the woman who featured in Mike Sonko’s viral expose, addressing the media on November 22, 2021. /COURTESY

Passaris accused Sonko of violating the rights of the woman and his expose that centred on her in a compromising situation was tantamount to online violence.

“That kind of violence and violation of a woman is wrong by every standard and I call on the DCI to take action against him because as a country, you can block someone who has terrorised and abused women on social media platforms,” she urged.

Passaris convinced the government to observe examples of other countries who have moved to tame the rogue actions of such individuals online, with an example of Europe which excludes the names of such individuals and their media denying them an audience

“Europe refuses to even mention the names of such people and they do not give them any kind of audience. So I am challenging the DCI and the DPP to close those social media platforms,” she added.

Passaris then went on to state that the actions taken by the government on Sonko should serve as an example to the rest as the country moves to end sexual and gender-based violence.

“If we say that we are going to end sexual and gender-based violence then perpetrators in such high positions should not be let to walk scot-free. He must be made an example of,” she said.

She added by referring to Donald Trump who had his social media accounts frozen by the United States (US) government on his way to losing the 2020 elections to current US President Joe Biden.

“Let us cut the power that perpetrators have on social media platforms. If they managed to do it to Donald Trump, then they can surely do it to Sonko,” she urged.

Sonko however appealed to the DCI and DPP as well as the witness protection agency and the Judicial Service Commission (JSC) to protect Nkatha after revealing that he had sensitive information to prove that she was coerced into giving false information.

He did not divulge further owing to the gag order issued against him that stopped him from further publishing the videos.

“…she’s not a witness in any of the cases before the Judicial Service Commission, the evidence I have to prove to the world that there’s massive corruption in the Judiciary is sufficient.

“I know after the video I released yesterday, all of you have been hostile and are planning bad things yet she is not a witness,” he stated.

Meanwhile, Sonko vowed that he would unmask seven more judges in the expose that uncovered the rot in the Kenyan Judiciary. This is even as the JSC probes into High Court Judge Said Juma Chitembwe’s alleged involvement in corruption.

“I am in possession of more dossiers touching 7 more Judges who have to undergo the same process for public confidence to be restored in the Kenyan Judiciary. It is not right to say that Judges are above the law.

“Judges are subject to the law in the same way as any other citizen,” he said.

headline: Detective Jane Mugo Appeals For Help After Attack By Unkown Gunmen
author: Marvin Chege

breadcrumbs.name: Detective Jane Mugo Appeals For Help After Attack By Unkown Gunmen

description: The incident which occurred on Thursday night, November 25 prompted police to launch investigations after she was allegedly kidnapped by six unidentified gunmen
articleBody:
Nairobi-based private detective Jane Mugo has appealed for help in financial terms after she escaped a near-death beating by unknown individuals.

The incident which occurred on Thursday night, November 25 prompted police to launch investigations after she was allegedly kidnapped by six unidentified gunmen who dumped her two colleagues in a forest before making away with her motor vehicle.

Taking to her Facebook page, the spy queen who became famous for her theatrics in a BBC investigative series, appealed to Kenyans to help raise funds to cover her pending medical bills.

”Good evening my fellow patriotic Kenyans. On behalf of my family, I wish to take this opportunity to thank you for the prayers, concerns, and solidarity you have shown, especially my followers and the medics who have been taking care of me during this darkest moment of my life.

“I was admitted to the hospital after sustaining head injuries and fractures on the hands during a carjacking incident at Burnt Forest area in Uasin Gishu County on Thursday night, November 25,” she wrote.

Mugo added that she had to undergo several surgeries as part of her treatment and that she was still recovering from her hospital bed.

”I have undergone several emergency surgeries to stabilize my condition and I am now fully conscious but still under medical observation.”

She added that her family had tried to raise funds for her medical bills, which shot up to six figures as of Friday, December 3.

”My family has been gathering funds to pay for the hospital bill which has already hit six figures as of today.”

She appealed to her followers and Kenyans at large to support her fundraiser in form of donations, adding that her card could only cater for part of the treatment.

”I am humbly asking for any of your support to my fundraising campaign for medical treatment since my card can only pay part of the bill. Any donations would be greatly appreciated,” she added.

and Gerishon Oliver, 26, who was seated on the rear seat, with all three heading to Kisumu County from Bungoma County.

An initial police report filed at the Eldama Ravine Police Station in Baringo County had revealed that the abductors blocked her vehicle with another vehicle and injured her face and hands with a machete.

“It has been reported by Olive who is a Luo male adult aged 26 years old and Newton Mkoyanzi a Luhya male adult aged 34 that they were on board a motor vehicle of registration number KCN 222K Toyota Land Cruiser TX belonging to one Jane Mugo,” the report read in part.

The spy queen days before the attack had hinted at vying for the Kirinyaga Woman Representative seat in the 2022 General Elections, adding that her decision to join politics was informed by her desire to serve the people of Kirinyaga County.
